<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_device_open:
```c
int metal_device_open(const char *bus_name, const char *dev_name,
		      struct metal_device **device)
{
	struct metal_bus *bus;
	int error;

	if (!bus_name || !strlen(bus_name) ||
	    !dev_name || !strlen(dev_name) ||
	    !device)
		return -EINVAL;

	error = metal_bus_find(bus_name, &bus);
	if (error)
		return error;

	if (!bus->ops.dev_open)
		return -ENODEV;

	error = (*bus->ops.dev_open)(bus, dev_name, device);
	if (error)
		return error;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
!strlen(bus_name)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: in the full expression (!bus_name || !strlen(bus_name) || ...), the left-to-right short-circuit evaluation of the || operator ensures strlen(bus_name) is only called if bus_name is non-NULL. Therefore this fragment does not itself cause an out-of-bounds access. (Note: if bus_name is non-NULL but not a NUL-terminated string, strlen could still read beyond the object bounds — that is a separate precondition/usage issue, not a consequence of this fragment's ordering.)
